name: sodium nitrate production, unrefined from caliche ore mining | sodium nitrate, unrefined | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20932/documentation

This activity represents the production of sodium nitrate from caliche ore mining in Chile. The largest natural accumulation of sodium nitrate in mineral deposits can be found in the Atacama Desert in northern Chile as a result of its unique arid climate going back to the middle Miocene epoch. These mineral deposits, called “caliche ore”, are mined for the production of sodium nitrate and iodine. The application of a leaching process leads to a solution rich in sodium nitrate and iodine (100 grams per litre (gpl) of concentration). To extract iodine, an optional by-product in this case, further sevaral processes in a separate plant need to be performed which are not included in the present modelling. The solid remainders of the leaching process are landfilled. The leaching mother liquid is kept in a loop, i.e. reused, so that initial input of the liquid is neglected in this dataset. ;

The activity starts with the mining of caliche ore from seams that are between 0.2 and 5 m thick on the surface under a layer of overburden material (0.5 – 1.5 m) using drilling machines, explosives, and bulldozers, etc. Sodium nitrate can then be dissolved after further crushing of the caliche ore (about 12 mm in diameter) and the application of a heated leaching process in big vats (at about 40°C). The leaching solution is mainly composed of the mother liquor from the nitrate crystallization process, weak brines generated in the washing stages of the leaching cycle, and fresh water to selectively dissolve the sodium nitrate. The solution rich in NaNO3 is sent to a crystallization process to separate sodium nitrate from the mother liquor by a centrifuge. 

The activity ends with the crystallization and separation of sodium nitrate reaching a grade of about 50%. This sodium nitrate is than used in the production of potassium nitrate or further procecced to higher purities.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Process data provided are from 2014/2015 and are valid for today's and near future production at SQM in Chile.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The production facilities are located in the Atacama Desert in northern Chile where the chemicals are produced from natural resources by the global producer and supplier SQM.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: SQM continueously improves this process to increase production volume and its efficiency.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data have been provided by the producer SQM in Chile.  SQM is a global producer and supplier of plant nutrients, iodine, lithium and industrial chemicals. The production facilities are located in the Atacama Desert where the chemicals are produced from natural resources via mining, crystalization and refining processes. Initially, some data and process information has been exchanged via questionaires. Further, more specific data were provided via intensive direct contact with experts at SQM.

flow.name: sodium nitrate, unrefined
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

exchanges.description: The water is generally kept in closed loops for the leaching and washing process. Due to general losses (evaporation, leaching), 2.4 kg of river, and tap water need to be added per kg of sodium nitrate produced.
Communication by SQM: If production levels are equivalent to current ones, confirmed reserves of the salar that belong to SQM will last at least for 30 more years.

Caliche ore mineral component. 1kg of caliche ore consists of 0.14 kg of sodium sulphate based on average spectroscopy measurements. In total 4.58 kg of caliche ore is required to produce 1kg of sodium nitrate, purity 50%

According to estimates, the Atacama Desert occupies 105,000 km2. Most of the desert is composed of stony terrain, salt lakes (salares), sand, and is extremly arid. The desert has rich deposits of copper and other minerals and the world's largest natural supply of sodium nitrate.
The solid remainders, e.g. resiual gangue, magnesium of the leaching process are landfilled.
